Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The aim of the proposed research on ?Nanorod Assembly in Polymeric Matrices? is to understand the fundamental principles that drive nanorod assembly when spatially confined. An underlying theme is controlling the location, alignment and packing of nanorods to optimize targeted properties. The work to be undertaken during this project involves
(1) orienting gold nanorods in homopolymer thin films and lamellar block copolymer films that confine the nanorods, and measuring their polarization dependent optical properties;
(2) applying thermodynamic principles to design systems that incorporate and align gold nanorods within cylindrical domains of block copolymers, and then studying nanorod induced phase transformations in block copolymer morphologies; and
(3) investigating unique nanorods including TiO2, silica with a gold nanoshell and Janus nanorod systems to explore how rod diameter, surface functionality, and biphasic surfaces direct the location of nanorods in block copolymers.
A successful outcome of the proposed research will be precise control over assembly of functional nanorods in polymer films using spatial confinement. As a proof of concept, a nanorod/polymer device will be fabricated and its polarization-dependent optical properties tested to demonstrate that these coating can be used as color polarizing filters.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polymer nanocomposites (PNCs) are utilized in applications ranging from sports (golf balls) to transportation (tires) because they combine materials with synergistic properties. Presently, PNCs are attracting interest for information storage as well as electronic and energy applications. The proposed research will provide scientists with the rules for selecting the materials that will lead to optimum efficiency in PNCs. The broader impacts include laboratory experience for middle and high school students, high school teachers and undergraduates including those from underrepresented groups. An annual science day for middle school students (6th ? 8th grade) will continue at the University of Pennsylvania. In addition, female elementary school students are introduced to a summer camp called Girls in Engineering Math & Science Camp (GEMS). A successful partnership with Central High School (CHS) in Philadelphia that has already resulted in a new innovative Materials Science course will continue. Future plans include extending the course from one to two sections, developing laboratories, exposing students to new characterization tools, and facilitating joint research projects. The first materials science textbook aimed at high school students is also planned. Because CHS draws academically talented, multicultural and diverse (32% African American, 5% Latino, 50% female) students, this partnership will have a profound and lasting impact on the scientific and technological literacy of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The introduction of new polymers has slowed significantly since the discovery of commodity polymers such as nylon used in clothing, TeflonTM coatings in non-stick frying pans, and polyethylene containers for liquids.  From the 1970’s and 80’s, the research focus moved towards understanding basic properties of polymers particularly those design rules involved with blending existing polymers to create less expensive materials with better properties than single older polymers. Currently, the combination of (nano)particles and polymers is of great importance, in part, because the cost to scale up production of newly discovered polymers is a huge challenge for struggling US chemical companies.   Moreover, modern society is driving the need for new materials with properties not typically associated with polymers such as capturing and storing energy. Polymer nanocomposites have the additional advantage of remaining easy to process and flexible, while displaying the strength and functionality typically associated with hard materials like metals.  One recent example success story is the polymer composite used in the Boeing 787 that allows for lighter planes, saving fuel costs, while improving passenger comfort because the cabin can withstand more humid conditions. Understanding the conditions under which the particles in such composites can be dispersed is a critical factor in achieving and maintaining the desired properties of polymer composites. 

The intellectual merit of the proposed research is to understand the principles that determine the dispersion of elongated nanoparticles in polymer nanocomposite films. By grafting long chains on metallic nanorods, the dispersion and aggregation of the nanorods could be controlled.  Moreover, upon aggregation, the size of the aggregates and the exact spacing between nanorods could be tuned resulting in control over the optical properties, such as color and absorption, of polymeric nanocomposite coatings.  Because both experiments and simulations of particle dispersion in polymers are found to be in excellent agreement, new combinations of nanoparticles and polymers can be envisioned resulting in properties previously unavailable.   Specifically, the design rules uncovered are independent of particle type.  The broader impacts resulting from the proposed activity are fourfold. First, polymer nanocomposites are of current industrial and future technological importance. By understanding the principles that underlie nanorod behavior in polymeric films, this research provides guidelines for judiciously incorporating anisotropic particles with unique optical, electronic, magnetic and semiconducting properties into host materials. Second, over fifty scientists were engaged in polymer nanocomposite research including high school teachers and students, undergraduates, graduate students, post-doctoral students, industrial scientists, scientists from national laboratories and junior faculty. Of particular note is the number of publications co-authored by undergraduates.  Third, the PI’s research group participated in the annual Philly Materials Day, Nanoday@Penn, workshops for K-12 teachers and presentations to local middle and high schools. By teaching, these students became much better scientists because they found that explaining even simple topics, like the elasticity of rubber bands, requires understanding the audience that is receiving the information.  Fourth, a successful partnership with Central High School in Philadelphia, begun in 2008, continues to teach Materials Science and Nanotechnology to underrepresented minorities in a multiracial, economically diverse, and talented student body at a magnet school where 99% of the students attend college.
